properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winds of 70 km/h expected this evening over exposed coastal locations. A front approaching from the northwest will cause winds to rise to 70 km/h over exposed coastal sections later this afternoon and persist until near midnight. Winds will ease overnight and Sunday morning as the front moves inland. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T12:34:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-16T22:41:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3040144963.2019
Area: East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong and cold northwesterly winds blowing over relatively warm Gulf of St. Lawrence waters make it possible for snow squalls to develop tonight. Conditions are expected to improve late overnight or Sunday morning when a ridge of high pressure moves over the region. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T13:59:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T02:33:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3986811035.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Stuartburn
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-17T16:30:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-16T15:21:30-06:00, 0ECA160B-D32C-B255-DCCA-3327B8AE3B59
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong winds that may cause damage are expected to begin overnight tonight. Sustained winds of 70 km/h with gusts to 100 km/h are beginning to develop over western Alberta. Gusts may reach as high as 120 km/h in southwestern regions of Alberta overnight tonight. Winds are expected to remain strong into Sunday morning before slowly weakening late Sunday afternoon. Strong gusty winds are forecast throughout the mountain parks and foothills regions. Please refer to local forecasts for regions not currently included in this warning. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T20:15:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T04:16:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0752452420.2019

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rain is expected for the inland sections of the north and central coasts, the Sunshine Coast and Howe Sound. An atmospheric river aimed at North Vancouver Island and the Central Coast will move southward tonight and Sunday morning. Rain will ease by Sunday morning and total rainfall amounts of 50 to 70 mm are expected. Given the tropical origin of the atmospheric river, freezing levels will be on the rise, reaching near 3000 metres for the South Coast and close to 2500 metres for the North Coast. The mild air will result in rain at almost all elevations and steady temperatures overnight. High runoff and rising river levels are likely through the weekend. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T16:12:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T00:13:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2892700088.2019
Area: Central Coast - inland sections, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Howe Sound, North Coast - inland including Kitimat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will move across the BC interior tonight and tomorrow. Light snow this evening will become heavier overnight and continue into Sunday. Total snowfall accumulations of 20 to 30 cm can be expected by later Sunday before the snow changes to a few rain showers. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T16:30:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T00:31:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3144964148.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain is forecast for parts of Metro Vancouver tonight. An atmospheric river aimed at northern Vancouver Island and the central coast of BC will move through the lower mainland tonight. Rain and wind will intensify with the arrival of the front and mild conditions will persist through Sunday. The heaviest rainfall is expected to be near the mountains with amounts near 40 to 50 mm before ending Sunday morning. Given the tropical origin of the atmospheric river, freezing levels will be on the rise, reaching near 3000 metres. The mild air will result in rain at almost all elevations and steady temperatures tonight. High runoff and rising river levels are likely through the weekend. The public is encouraged to monitor rainfall and wind warnings from Environment and Climate Change Canada as well as potential high streamflow advisories or flood watches from the BC River Forecast Centre. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T16:13:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T00:14:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1718593471.2019
Area: Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

Time span: until after midnight in the Rigolet area and early Sunday morning from Cartwright to Black Tickle. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system from the U.S. eastern seaboard could hit Southern Quebec with a mixed bag of precipitation Monday evening. Precipitation is expected to begin as freezing rain before changing over to snow in the overnight hours. Ice accretion could be significant in a few areas making roads and other surfaces slippery. The exact track of this system remains uncertain and, as a result, so do the areas at risk. More details will be provided in future forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T20:02:56-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. An area of high pressure entrenched over the Mackenzie basin will combine with an approaching low over the Gulf of Alaska will produce strong winds and blizzard conditions to the Dempster highway. Winds up to 110 km/h and falling snow will produce blizzard conditions near the Richardson mountains. The blizzard will begin overnight Saturday and persist until late Sunday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T15:22:11-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A moisture-laden Pacific frontal system will bring significant snowfall and the risk of freezing rain to Watson Lake. Snowfall will begin this afternoon and intensify this evening. Snow, heavy at times, will continue until Sunday evening. Total snowfall accumulation will likely exceed 25 cm. Around midday on Sunday there is also the risk of freezing rain or ice pellets occurring as well. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.

Area: Watson Lake

properties.Summary:

Locations: Hopedale to Makkovik. Time span: gradually easing through the night. Remarks: The strong northwesterly winds and poor visibility in snow and blowing snow will slowly improve overnight into Sunday morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard late tonight and most of Sunday. A low pressure system just east of Chesterfield Inlet is forecast to track northeast and intensify over Southampton Island tonight. Winds are strengthening out of the north at Naujaat this evening, which along with falling snow will create blizzard or near blizzard conditions beginning by midnight. The worst conditions will be from late overnight through Sunday morning with north winds of 50 to 60 km/h and gusts of 70 or 80 creating blizzard conditions. Visibilities will begin to improve late Sunday afternoon as the winds slowly diminish with continued improvement Sunday night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-17T20:09:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-17T04:10:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3292521518.2019
Area: Naujaat
properties.Author: Environment Canada
